title: 111_hr3530
content: The "Greener Gardens Act of 2009" allows for a credit for qualified nonroad equipment under section 30E of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Greener Gardens Act of 2009" provides a tax credit of 25% for qualified nonroad equipment expenses, limited to $1,000 per unit placed in service by the taxpayer in the taxable year. Qualified nonroad equipment expenses include the cost of equipment used primarily by the taxpayer and placed in service during the year. The "Greener Gardens Act of 2009" offers a 25% tax credit for qualified nonroad equipment expenses, up to $1,000 per unit placed in service by the taxpayer. Qualified equipment includes items primarily used for lawn, garden, or forestry purposes, with specific requirements for hybrid-electric drive trains or cutting systems. The text chunk discusses the regulations for new compression-ignition engines under specific parts of title 40, Code of Federal Regulations, ensuring compliance with exhaust and evaporative emissions standards set by the Environmental Protection Agency. The text chunk discusses equipment powered by alternative power sources such as solar power, electricity, or rechargeable batteries, regulated by the Environmental Protection Agency for use with 100 percent biodiesel. The text chunk pertains to a new spark-ignition engine certified by the Environmental Protection Agency to emit no more than 50 percent of regulated pollutants under specific standards. The curr_chunk discusses federal regulations related to handheld and nonhandheld engines, defines alternative power sources, and excludes certain components from the term 'unit'. It also addresses the application of the credit with other credits. The curr_chunk discusses the treatment of credits for depreciation on property and personal credits under subsection (a) for taxable years. It also includes limitations based on the amount of tax for certain taxable years. The credit allowed under subsection (a) for any taxable year is limited by the regular tax liability plus the tax imposed by section 55, minus the credits allowable under subpart A and section 27. The basis of property eligible for the credit is reduced by the amount of the credit allowed. The section allows a credit for certain property without double benefits. It terminates for specific equipment after set timeframes. Conforming amendments are made to related sections of the Internal Revenue Code. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to include section 30E for tax credits on specific equipment. This credit is integrated into the business credit section of the Code. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new section 36 for the qualified nonroad equipment credit. This amendment follows the integration of section 30E for tax credits on specific equipment into the business credit section of the Code. The new section 36 of the Internal Revenue Code provides a credit for qualified nonroad equipment, effective for property placed in service after the enactment of the Act.
